STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 12, 2022
Robert Powell
Family Services & Children's Aid - Jackson County
PO Box 6128
330 West Michigan Ave.
Jackson, MI 49204
RE: License #: CB380201116
Family Service & Children's Aid - Jackson County
330 W Michigan
Jackson, MI 49204
Dear Ms. Powell:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on July 7, 2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following: (d) Compliance with the
licensing rules for foster homes.
One of three foster home reevaluations did not accurately document compliance
with a foster home licensing rule.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(e) A list of all children currently placed in the home.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
(h) A copy of the current children's foster home license
application and children's foster home licensing transaction
record documents from the certifying agency.
Two of two borrowed bed files did not have the documentation required by e, f, g,
and h of this rule, prior to the borrowed bed agreement beginning.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(2) The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d), (e), (g), (h), and (i) of this rule
annually for the duration of the child's placement.
One of two borrowed bed files did not have updated documentation as required by
this rule.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of three foster home files held a late USP. The 10/11/21-1/8/22 USP was
completed on 1/20/22.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility…
4

One of three foster care cases did not meet this requirement.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
One of three adoption evaluations was not completed timely. The application was
signed on 10/4/21; the evaluation was completed on 2/2/22.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/8/2020 INTERIM, CAP approved 8/10/2020
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation
(4)An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
Two of three adoption files did not have documentation the evaluation and
recommendation were provided to the family as required.
R 400.12405 Change of placement
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary, then all
of the documentation required in subrules (2) and (3) of this rule
shall be in the child’s record within 14 calendar days after the
change in placement.
One of three foster care files did not have the required documentation for moves on
4/8/22 and 4/17/22.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting
Page 1
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
5

One of three foster care files did not have documentation of the parents or foster
parent being invited to an FTM on 6/2/22.
FOM 722-08E Foster care/juvenile justice action summary
Pages 2-6
(Page 2) Within three business days of change in caseworker or
organization, the new caseworker must document the following
for the former and new caseworker…
(Page 6) Within three business days of foster care or juvenile
justice program or case closure, the caseworker must
document:
(Page 2) One of three foster care files held documentation that was not completed
within the required time frame. The case was accepted on 3/18/22 and the DHHS-69
completed on 4/14/22.
(Page 6) Two of two closed foster care files did not have a closing DHHS-69
completed.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Page 19
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
One of three foster care cases and one of one IL cases did not meet this
requirement. Case contacts were entered 4-20 days late.
FOM 722-08 Case service plans-overview, types, and timeframes
Page 11
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Two of fifteen FC and IL USPs were approved late. One USP dated 2/28/22 was
approved on 3/15/22. The other USP, dated 10/10/21, was approved on 10/26/21.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Page 10
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
One of fifteen PATPs held late signatures by the parents and foster parent. The
signatures were approximately seven days late.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
Page 2
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
One of three foster care files did not have a medical passport updated quarterly for
September and December 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
5/19/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/26/2021
6

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 When completing a licensing reevaluation, the recommendations on the 3080,
3706, and evaluation must all match.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The CAP, approved 5/26/21, was a result of the 5/19/21 renewal evaluation. Overall,
the agency has shown compliance with the 2021 CAP. During this review, there was
one repeat violation regarding medical passports, which occurred in one of three
cases reviewed. The agency had thirteen violations overall for 2022. While this is an
increase from last year, the violations occurred in 1 of 3, or 2 of 3 files reviewed. The
violations are attributed to staffing changes and difficulties in completing items due
to COVID restrictions.
Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA)
The CAA was reviewed and discussed on-site. The CAA reported an internal audit
was completed prior to the DCWL evaluation, to assess their CAP implementation.
Overall, the agency found compliance with the CAP was achieved in many areas.
Areas of needed improvement included timeliness of adoption home studies and
medical/dental documentation. The agency reported COVID restrictions and staffing
changes impacted compliance throughout the year. However, they have been
completing a lot of training with all staff this year and have recently hired a new
supervisor, which will help staff have more consistency.
Interviews
Interviews were completed on-site with licensing, adoption, and foster care staff.
Staff reported feeling supported and having a knowledgeable supervisor. Staff stated
their caseloads are manageable and work schedule is flexible. Staff did not have any
concerns or suggestions for improvement at the agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
7

an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
_ _____________July 11, 2022______________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 11, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
8
